docs.title: Murtha Cancer Center Data Platform Documentation
docs.text: The Murtha Cancer Center Data Platform (MC2DP) is a Gen3 data mesh supporting the Prometheus Project.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Discover and study advanced precision technologies that will enable prevention, early detection, and enhanced treatments of cancers potentially arising due to exposures to environmental contaminants and toxin hazards by military service members and veterans.

docs.title: Vision
docs.text: Integrate federal scientific platforms with public-private innovators revealing the impact of service-related exposures to environmental contaminants and toxin hazards and developing prevention and early detection approaches and advanced treatments of cancers arising from these exposures.

docs.title: Capabilities
docs.text:
• Integrates multiple data commons and repositories, enabling seamless data connectivity and interoperability between various data sources.
  • Represents a dynamic Data Ecosystem that aggregates and hosts metadata from multiple resources to make data discovery and access easy for users.

MC2DP is powered by the open-source software “Gen3”.

MC2DP was created by and is actively developed at the University of Chicago’s Center for Translational Data Science (CTDS) and the Open Commons Consortium (OCC) with the aim of creating interoperable cloud-based data resources for the scientific research community.

docs.title: Analysis Page
docs.text:
The Analysis Page houses example analysis performed in MC2DP. These examples can be used to demonstrate the capabilities of MC2DP.

Each example can be viewed as an HTML but is also available as a Jupyter Notebook in the Example Analysis directory of a users Workspace.

docs.title: Contact MC2DP Support
docs.text: Need help? Please contact our help desk at - support@gen3.org

docs.title: Data Connections Page
docs.text:
The Data Connections Page provides users with a concurrent summary of the data contained in MC2DP via data connections.

The table summarizes data connection and is updated by the Data Curation team as connections are established or updated.

The legend specifies the manner of the connection made from an external source to MC2DP. The categories include: - (green) - connection established with real data - (yellow) - connection established with synthetic data - (red) - connection not worrking/connection pending/data pending

docs.title: Data Library Page
docs.text:
Users must login before viewing the Data Library Page.

The data library stores cohorts and data selections from that user in the Exploration Page.

docs.title: Exploration Page
docs.text:
The primary tool for exploring data within MC2DP is the Exploration Page, which offers faceted search of data across data sources. This page can be accessed from the /explorer endpoint or the top navigation bar, by clicking on the “Exploration” icon.

The Exploration page is derived from a series of Elastic Search Indicies that enables a performant search and filter of all MC2DP metadata. Data cards display dynamic visual summaries of important dataset feature and the main data table below displays the available metadata records based on current filter selections.

Users are able to build and save cohorts presented in the Explorer with the Cohort Selector tool.

docs.title: Cohort Selector in the Exploration Page
docs.text:
To build a cohort in the Exploration page, first create or select a cohort in the selection tool section.

Filters on the left control for several data attributes and update the main data displayed in the charts and tables as well as updates the cohort you're building.

The main table displays a sample of the data being selected.

docs.title: FAIR Data Principles
docs.text:
MC2DP provides secure access to study metadata from multiple external resources and will be the driving engine for new discovery. The types of data represented are varied and include scientific research across multiple disciplines.

MC2DP aims to make data more accessible by following the "FAIR" principles:

Findable: Researchers are provided an intuitive interface to search over metadata for all studies and related datasets. Each study and dataset will be assigned a unique, persistent identifier.

Accessible: Authenticated users can request and receive access to controlled-access data by data providers. Metadata can be accessed via an open API.

Interoperable: Data can be easily exported to various workspaces for analysis using a variety of software tools.

Reusable: Data can be easily reused to facilitate reproducibility of results, development and sharing of new tools, and collaboration between investigators.

docs.title: Login Access Overview
docs.text:
MC2DP is still under active development, so access to pages and data may change as a result.

All users are able to browse the study metadata in the Explorer Page as well as other pages without logging in.

Users will need to log in to obtain authorization (access) in order to: - Access the Data Library Page - Access the Workspace Page and run interactive tutorial notebooks.

Start by visiting the login page

Users are presented with two options: - Login with Google: You may login using any Google account credentials, or a G-suite enabled institutional email. This option may or may not be available depending on the institution or organization the user is associated with. - Login via ORCID: You can sign in using your ORCID iD credentials. This option may require your ORCID account to be linked to your institutional profile or application, depending on the organization’s requirements.

After successfully logging in, your username will appear in the upper right-hand corner of the page.

docs.title: Mesh Metadata Page
docs.text:
The Mesh Metadata Page provides users the minimal metadata required via a summary of the metadata available in MC2DP.

As both Study and Subject metadata is available in MC2DP from many data sources a tab for each can be selected to view the associated terms.

docs.title: Profile Page
docs.text:
On the profile page users will find information regarding their authorization to External Data Sources, and the function to create API keys for data access.

Authorization to any of the External Data Sources can be obtained or refreshed via the tiles at the top of the page.

Below, an API key can be created to access native MC2DP elements.

docs.title: Security and Downloading Results
docs.text:
MC2DP securely exposes study metadata and data files stored on multiple External FAIR repositories and Data Commons, i.e. data libraries or archives, to provide an easy way to connect different repositories on one single location.

Data is not directly located in MC2DP, so any raw data accessed in MC2DP is in fact accessed from the associated data resource.

docs.title: Data Security and Downloading Results in Workspaces
docs.text:
Data Security in the Workspaces is managed by the Gen3 microservice Fence.

Authorizations managed in the Profile Page are transferred into a users workspace when it is initiated.

docs.title: Getting Started in Workspaces
docs.text:
MC2DP workspaces are secure data analysis environments in the cloud that can access data from one or more data resources. By default, Workspaces include Jupyter notebooks at this time.

New to Jupyter? Learn more about the popular tool for data scientists on Jupyter.org (disclaimer: CTDS is not responsible for the content).

docs.title: Guidline to get started in Workspaces
docs.text:
Once users have access to workspaces, use this guide below to get started with analysis work in workspaces.

  1. Users need to log in via https://mc2dp.data-commons.org/login to access workspaces.

  2. After navigating to https://mc2dp.data-commons.org/workspace, users will discover a list of pre-configured virtual machine (VM) images, as shown below.

  1. Click “Launch” on any of the workspace options to spin up a copy of that VM. The status of launching the workspace is displayed after clicking on “Launch”. Note: Launching the VM may take several minutes.

  1. After launching, the home folders are displayed. One of these folders is the user's persistent drive (/pd).

  1. Select the /pd folder. New files or licenses should be saved in the the /pd directory if users need to access them after restarting the workspaces. Only files saved in the /pd directory will remain available after termination of a workspace session.

    • Use this folder to store files (notebooks, data files, etc) that you want to use again later. The files you save here will still be available when you come back after terminating your workspace session.
    • Any files you create or add outside of this folder will be lost if they are not moved to the /pd before your workspace session terminates.

  2. Start a new notebook under “Notebook” in the Launcher tab. Click the tiles in the launcher and choose between Python 3 or R Studio as the base programmatic language.

  1. Experiment away! Code blocks are entered in cells, which can be executed individually or all at once. Code documentation and comments can also be entered in cells, and the cell type can be set to support Markdown.

  2. Do not forget to close your workspace once your work is finished. Unclosed workspaces continue to accrue computational costs. Note, Workspaces automatically shut down after several minutes of idle time.
